data.name: AsyncCallInsideUsingBlockDescription
data.value: When an async method is called without await inside a using block, the disposable resource may be disposed before the async operation completes, causing exceptions or undefined behavior. Always await async calls that depend on resources in the using scope.

data.name: AsyncCallInsideUsingBlockMessageFormat
data.value: '{0}' is not awaited inside a using block - the resource may be disposed before the async operation completes. Add 'await' to ensure proper resource lifetime.

data.name: AsyncCallInsideUsingBlockTitle
data.value: Fire-and-forget async call inside a using block

data.name: AsyncVoidDescription
data.value: Async void methods cannot be awaited, making it impossible to know when they complete or to catch their exceptions. Exceptions thrown in async void methods will crash the process. Use 'async Task' instead, which allows proper exception handling and await support. The only valid use case for async void is event handlers.
data.comment: An optional longer localizable description of the diagnostic.

data.name: AsyncVoidFixerTitle
data.value: Convert void to Task

data.name: AsyncVoidMessageFormat
data.value: Async void method or delegate detected - use 'async Task' instead. Async void cannot be awaited and unhandled exceptions will crash the process. Only event handlers should use async void.
data.comment: The format-able message the diagnostic displays.

data.name: AsyncVoidTitle
data.value: Fire-and-forget async-void methods or delegates

data.name: BlockingCallInsideAsyncDescription
data.value: Blocking calls like Task.Result, Task.Wait(), Thread.Sleep(), or Task.GetAwaiter().GetResult() inside async methods can cause deadlocks, especially in UI or ASP.NET contexts with synchronization contexts. Use the async equivalents: await instead of .Result/.Wait(), Task.Delay() instead of Thread.Sleep(), Task.WhenAll() instead of Task.WaitAll().

data.name: BlockingCallInsideAsyncFixerTitle
data.value: Replace with async equivalent

data.name: BlockingCallInsideAsyncMessageFormat
data.value: Blocking call '{1}' can cause deadlocks in async code. Use '{0}' instead.

data.name: BlockingCallInsideAsyncTitle
data.value: Blocking call inside an async method

data.name: NestedTaskToOuterTaskDescription
data.value: Using TaskFactory.StartNew() with an async lambda creates a Task<Task> (nested task). Awaiting only the outer task doesn't wait for the inner async operation to complete. Use Task.Run() instead, which automatically unwraps async lambdas, or call .Unwrap() on the result.

data.name: NestedTaskToOuterTaskMessageFormat
data.value: Task<Task> detected from async lambda - awaiting only the outer task won't wait for completion. Use Task.Run() instead of TaskFactory.StartNew(), or call .Unwrap() to get the inner task.

data.name: NestedTaskToOuterTaskTitle
data.value: Nested Task<Task> from TaskFactory.StartNew with async lambda

data.name: UnnecessaryAsyncDescription
data.value: When a method only awaits a single expression as its last statement and returns the result, the async/await keywords add unnecessary overhead. Return the Task directly and let the caller await it. This reduces state machine allocation and improves performance. Exception: Keep async/await when you need try/catch around the await or when the method has multiple awaits.

data.name: UnnecessaryAsyncFixerTitle
data.value: Remove async/await and return Task directly

data.name: UnnecessaryAsyncMessageFormat
data.value: Method '{0}' only awaits a single expression - remove async/await and return the Task directly to reduce overhead

data.name: UnnecessaryAsyncTitle
data.value: Unnecessary async/await usage

data.name: ImplicitTaskTypeMismatchDescription
data.value: A non-async lambda returning Task<T> is being assigned to a delegate expecting Task (e.g., Func<Task>). The result value is silently discarded due to implicit conversion from Task<T> to Task. Unlike async lambdas which produce compiler error CS8031 for this pattern, non-async lambdas compile without warning. Either change the delegate type to Func<Task<T>> to preserve the result, or explicitly discard it if intentional.

data.name: ImplicitTaskTypeMismatchMessageFormat
data.value: Lambda returns Task<T> but delegate expects Task - the result is silently discarded. Change delegate to Func<Task<T>> or explicitly discard the result.

data.name: ImplicitTaskTypeMismatchTitle
data.value: Task<T> to Task conversion silently discards result
